articles.headline: Must Haves: Cellphones Top Iraqi Cool List
articles.snippet: Cellphones are a window into Iraqis’ macabre sense of humor and their resilience amid the swells of violence.
articles.abstract: Cellphones are a window into Iraqis’ macabre sense of humor and their resilience amid the swells of violence.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 7 — The cool kids in Iraq all want an Apache, the cellphone they’ve named after an American military helicopter. Next on the scale of hipness comes a Humvee, followed by the Afendi, a Turkish word for dapper, and a sturdy, rounded Nokia known as the Allawi — a reference to the stocky former prime minister, Ayad Allawi.

articles.headline: After Bomb Kills Loved Ones, Life Turns Ghostly
articles.snippet: Ghazi Samra stumbles on through grief and regret after an Israeli airstrike killed his wife, daughter and granddaughter.
articles.abstract: Ghazi Samra stumbles on through grief and regret after an Israeli airstrike killed his wife, daughter and granddaughter.
articles.lead_paragraph: TYRE, Lebanon, Aug. 7 — After a bomb hits, the remains of a life are modest.

articles.headline: Google Deal Will Give News Corp. Huge Payoff
articles.snippet: Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com and other News Corporation sites.
articles.abstract: Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com and other News Corporation sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com, the social networking phenomenon, and other Web sites owned by the News Corporation.

articles.headline: Stewart Deal Resolves Stock Case
articles.snippet: Martha Stewart agreed to pay $195,000 to settle insider-trading accusations, concluding a five-year legal battle.
articles.abstract: Martha Stewart agreed to pay $195,000 to settle insider-trading accusations, concluding a five-year legal battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martha Stewart, the celebrated domestic tastemaker, reached an agreement yesterday with securities regulators to settle insider-trading accusations, concluding a five-year legal battle that once put a dent in her brand.

articles.headline: Court Rules for I.B.M. on Pension
articles.snippet: An appellate panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999.
articles.abstract: An appellate panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999.
articles.lead_paragraph: A three-judge appellate panel ruled yesterday that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999, a long-awaited decision that could help shelter hundreds of companies from possible age discrimination suits.

articles.headline: A Forbes Family Fund-Raiser
articles.snippet: Forbes magazine may call itself the “capitalist tool,” but it apparently no longer produces enough capital to support the family empire.
articles.abstract: Forbes magazine may call itself the “capitalist tool,” but it apparently no longer produces enough capital to support the family empire.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before Madonna and Donald Trump, Malcolm Forbes strode across the world stage creating his own brand, embodying the magazine he published and the lifestyle it represented.

articles.headline: Public Pension Plans Face Billions in Shortages
articles.snippet: By one estimate, state and local governments owe roughly $375 billion more than they have committed to their pension funds.
articles.abstract: By one estimate, state and local governments owe roughly $375 billion more than they have committed to their pension funds.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2003, a whistle-blower forced San Diego to reveal that it had been shortchanging its city workers’ pension fund for years, setting off a wave of lawsuits, investigations and eventually criminal indictments.

articles.headline: Biggest Oil Field in U.S. Is Forced to Stop Pumping
articles.snippet: The emergency at BP's Prudhoe Bay operation in Alaska drove world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel.
articles.abstract: The emergency at BP's Prudhoe Bay operation in Alaska drove world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel.
articles.lead_paragraph: BP began shutting down the nation’s largest oil field yesterday after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Prudhoe Bay operation in Alaska. The emergency drove already-high world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: China Turns Out Mummified Bodies for Displays
articles.snippet: A ghastly underground mini-industry has emerged in China, preparing human corpses for museum exhibitions.
articles.abstract: A ghastly underground mini-industry has emerged in China, preparing human corpses for museum exhibitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALIAN, China — Tucked away in the back of this coastal city’s export-oriented manufacturing zone is a place that can only be described as a modern mummification factory.

articles.headline: A Deal Maker Jerry Garcia Might Have Liked
articles.snippet: What does the lead singer of a rock band want with a financial magazine empire?     That was the question Wall Street bankers were whispering yesterday after the Forbes family said that it had sold a minority interest in its publishing business to...
articles.abstract: What does the lead singer of a rock band want with a financial magazine empire?     That was the question Wall Street bankers were whispering yesterday after the Forbes family said that it had sold a minority interest in its publishing business to Elevation Partners, a private equity firm that counts Bono of U2 as a managing director.
articles.lead_paragraph: What does the lead singer of a rock band want with a financial magazine empire?

articles.headline: China Turns Out Mummified Bodies for Displays
articles.snippet: Tucked away in the back of this coastal city's export-oriented manufacturing zone is a place that can only be described as a modern mummification factory.     Inside a series of unmarked buildings, hundreds of Chinese workers, some seated in assem...
articles.abstract: Tucked away in the back of this coastal city's export-oriented manufacturing zone is a place that can only be described as a modern mummification factory.     Inside a series of unmarked buildings, hundreds of Chinese workers, some seated in assembly line formations, are cleaning, cutting, dissecting, preserving and re-engineering human corpses, preparing them for the international museum exhibition market.
articles.lead_paragraph: DALIAN, China - Tucked away in the back of this coastal city's export-oriented manufacturing zone is a place that can only be described as a modern mummification factory.

articles.headline: Google Deal Will Give News Corp. Huge Payoff
articles.snippet: Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com, the social networking phenomenon, and other Web sites owned by the News Corporation.     The deal promises to pay the News Corporation a minimum of $900 millio...
articles.abstract: Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com, the social networking phenomenon, and other Web sites owned by the News Corporation.     The deal promises to pay the News Corporation a minimum of $900 million over three and half years, a handsome payoff for its aggressive strategy of Internet acquisitions under its chairman and chief executive, Rupert Murdoch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google has won a bidding war to provide search services and advertising to MySpace.com, the social networking phenomenon, and other Web sites owned by the News Corporation.

articles.headline: Biggest Oil Field in U.S. Is Forced to Stop Pumping
articles.snippet: BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field yesterday after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Prudhoe Bay operation in Alaska. The emergency drove already-high world crude oil prices to...
articles.abstract: BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field yesterday after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Prudhoe Bay operation in Alaska. The emergency drove already-high world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel.     The company said that it would take three to five days to shut the pipeline system that serves Prudhoe Bay on the North Slope of Alaska. BP said it could not estimate how long the system would be down as it replaced all 16 miles of feeder pipelines that connect the Prudhoe Bay field with the larger Trans-Alaska Pipeline.
articles.lead_paragraph: BP began shutting down the nation's largest oil field yesterday after an inspection detected heavy corrosion and a small leak in a critical pipeline in its Prudhoe Bay operation in Alaska. The emergency drove already-high world crude oil prices to just under $77 a barrel.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Court Backs I.B.M. on Pensions
articles.snippet: A three-judge panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999. Page C1.
articles.abstract: A three-judge panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999. Page C1.
articles.lead_paragraph: A three-judge panel ruled that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999. Page C1.

articles.headline: Court Rules for I.B.M. on Pension
articles.snippet: A three-judge appellate panel ruled yesterday that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999, a long-awaited decision that could help shelter hundreds of companies from possible age discriminat...
articles.abstract: A three-judge appellate panel ruled yesterday that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999, a long-awaited decision that could help shelter hundreds of companies from possible age discrimination suits.     Yesterday's decision reversed a 2003 federal court ruling that changes International Business Machines made to its pension plan discriminated against older workers by making it impossible for their benefits to grow in value as much as the benefits of younger workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A three-judge appellate panel ruled yesterday that I.B.M. did not discriminate against its older workers when it switched retirement plans in 1999, a long-awaited decision that could help shelter hundreds of companies from possible age discrimination suits.

articles.headline: After Bomb Kills Loved Ones, Life Turns Ghostly
articles.snippet: After a bomb hits, the remains of a life are modest.     Ghazi Samra, a fisherman, is feeling the new shape of his. Last month, his wife, one of his daughters and a granddaughter were killed in an Israeli airstrike. Since then, his life has shrunk...
articles.abstract: After a bomb hits, the remains of a life are modest.     Ghazi Samra, a fisherman, is feeling the new shape of his. Last month, his wife, one of his daughters and a granddaughter were killed in an Israeli airstrike. Since then, his life has shrunk to the size of one crooked city block. He tries to sleep in an apartment that is not his own. He wears his wife's glasses, more out of a craving for closeness to her than as an aid to see. The shirt and shorts he is wearing are his brother's. He has not felt able to return to his own apartment.
articles.lead_paragraph: TYRE, Lebanon, Aug. 7 - After a bomb hits, the remains of a life are modest.

articles.headline: Public Pension Plans Face Billions in Shortages
articles.snippet: In 2003, a whistle-blower forced San Diego to reveal that it had been shortchanging its city workers' pension fund for years, setting off a wave of lawsuits, investigations and eventually criminal indictments.     The mayor ended up resigning unde...
articles.abstract: In 2003, a whistle-blower forced San Diego to reveal that it had been shortchanging its city workers' pension fund for years, setting off a wave of lawsuits, investigations and eventually criminal indictments.     The mayor ended up resigning under a cloud. With the city's books a shambles, San Diego remains barred from raising money by selling bonds. Cut off from a vital source of cash, it has fallen behind on its maintenance of streets, storm drains and public buildings. Potholes are proliferating and beaches are closed because of sewage spills.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2003, a whistle-blower forced San Diego to reveal that it had been shortchanging its city workers' pension fund for years, setting off a wave of lawsuits, investigations and eventually criminal indictments.

articles.headline: Must Haves: Cellphones Top Iraqi Cool List
articles.snippet: The cool kids in Iraq all want an Apache, the cellphone they've named after an American military helicopter. Next on the scale of hipness comes a Humvee, followed by the Afendi, a Turkish word for dapper, and a sturdy, rounded Nokia known as the A...
articles.abstract: The cool kids in Iraq all want an Apache, the cellphone they've named after an American military helicopter. Next on the scale of hipness comes a Humvee, followed by the Afendi, a Turkish word for dapper, and a sturdy, rounded Nokia known as the Allawi -- a reference to the stocky former prime minister, Ayad Allawi.     Even more telling are the text messages and images that Iraqis share over their phones. From all over the city, Baghdad cellphones practically shout commentary about Saddam Hussein, failed reconstruction and violence, always the violence. One of the most popular messages making the rounds appears onscreen with the image of a skeleton.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 7 - The cool kids in Iraq all want an Apache, the cellphone they've named after an American military helicopter. Next on the scale of hipness comes a Humvee, followed by the Afendi, a Turkish word for dapper, and a sturdy, rounded Nokia known as the Allawi -- a reference to the stocky former prime minister, Ayad Allawi.

articles.headline: Stewart Deal Resolves Stock Case
articles.snippet: Martha Stewart, the celebrated domestic tastemaker, reached an agreement yesterday with securities regulators to settle insider-trading accusations, concluding a five-year legal battle that once put a dent in her brand.      Under the settlement -...
articles.abstract: Martha Stewart, the celebrated domestic tastemaker, reached an agreement yesterday with securities regulators to settle insider-trading accusations, concluding a five-year legal battle that once put a dent in her brand.      Under the settlement -- the fruit of months of intense negotiations between her lawyers and the Securities and Exchange Commission -- Ms. Stewart must pay $195,000, covering her gains from the trading and penalties.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martha Stewart, the celebrated domestic tastemaker, reached an agreement yesterday with securities regulators to settle insider-trading accusations, concluding a five-year legal battle that once put a dent in her brand.

articles.headline: Israel Rejects Lebanon Offer
articles.snippet: Lebanon offered to deploy 15,000 of its troops in the southern part of the country if Israel entirely withdrew its forces. The overture was dismissed by the Israelis. Page A8.
articles.abstract: Lebanon offered to deploy 15,000 of its troops in the southern part of the country if Israel entirely withdrew its forces. The overture was dismissed by the Israelis. Page A8.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lebanon offered to deploy 15,000 of its troops in the southern part of the country if Israel entirely withdrew its forces. The overture was dismissed by the Israelis. Page A8.

articles.headline: A Forbes Family Fund-Raiser
articles.snippet: Long before Madonna and Donald Trump, Malcolm Forbes strode across the world stage creating his own brand, embodying the magazine he published and the lifestyle it represented.      In large measure, Mr. Forbes succeeded by combining an ability to...
articles.abstract: Long before Madonna and Donald Trump, Malcolm Forbes strode across the world stage creating his own brand, embodying the magazine he published and the lifestyle it represented.      In large measure, Mr. Forbes succeeded by combining an ability to pick great editors with a knack for teasing advertising dollars out of chief executives who were eager for invitations to his castle in France and his palace in Tangiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Long before Madonna and Donald Trump, Malcolm Forbes strode across the world stage creating his own brand, embodying the magazine he published and the lifestyle it represented.
